mainEntity.name: What type of garage door should I choose for replacement?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best garage door depends on your needs: **Steel** (durable, low-maintenance), **Wood** (aesthetic but requires upkeep), **Aluminum/Glass** (modern, good for natural light), or **Insulated Doors** (energy-efficient for attached garages). Consider climate, security, and curb appeal when choosing .

mainEntity.name: What size garage door do I need?

acceptedAnswer.text: Standard sizes are **8x7 ft** (single-car) or **16x7 ft** (double-car), but custom sizes exist. Measure the **opening width and height**, headroom (space above), and side room (space beside tracks). Professional measurement is recommended for accuracy .

mainEntity.name: Should I install a garage door opener with my new door?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, if your old opener is outdated (over 10–15 years) or incompatible with the new door. Modern openers offer **smart connectivity, battery backup, and quieter operation**. A professional can ensure proper synchronization for safety and efficiency .

mainEntity.name: How much does a garage door replacement cost?

acceptedAnswer.text: Average costs range from **$750–$2,500**, depending on material, size, insulation, and labor. Basic steel doors start at ~$800, while custom wood or high-end insulated doors can exceed $4,000. Additional costs apply for openers or structural adjustments .

mainEntity.name: Can I replace a single damaged panel instead of the whole door?

acceptedAnswer.text: Yes, **sectional garage doors** allow single-panel replacement ($150–$800 per panel), but older doors may require a full replacement if parts are discontinued. Tilt-up or one-piece doors must be fully replaced. A pro can assess compatibility and color matching .
